It's worked for me in the past when I configured it as follows:

server {
  listen 80 default_server;
  listen [::]:80 default_server ipv6only=on;

  location / {
    proxy_http_version 1.1;
    proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:6006;
  }
}

Since you're chrooting the app, you need to take into consideration that asset and XHR requests get sent to a whole bunch of other endpoints (e.g. /data, /runs, etc.) using absolute paths.

Refactoring TensorBoard to make all asset requests relative, and then maybe rooting XHRs under a single prefix like /_/tensorboard/ would be nice (CC: @dandelionmane) but also a nontrivial undertaking.

I would recommend creating a separate hostname for TensorBoard. For example, say http://tensorboard.you.com rather than http://you.com/tensorboard. Then configure a virtual host in nginx.

You wouldn't by any chance be building a productionized service for TensorBoard? Because if that's something you're interested in having, we should talk more.
